Projects

Handcrafted CSS

March 15, 2013

8th Light is all about craftsmanship. Doing something we are proud of doing & doing it with enthusiasm, passion, and skill. Dan Cederholm, author of Handcrafted CSS, is obviously a huge proponent of this same mindset, making this book an appropriate addition to my reading.

Handcrafted CSS does something important: it allows us to style things the way we want, while giving us tools to assure that these things degrade gracefully when being viewed with a lesser browser. Responsiveness is something that I have been learning about slowly through this apprenticeship, and is definitely a consideration---not only making things that are supported on smaller devices, but also making things that will be supported on older browsers. While I like to think that I'd make something akin to a 404 error message for people with Internet Explorer ("Too bad, maybe you should upgrade to something relevant!"), for some clients, that is obviously not an option. In some occupations, it is common for users to still be booting up a Windows 98 computer and running Internet Explorer 6-8. While we may weep at this very idea, we must also accept it and adapt to it by coming up with new ways to display things the way we want.

"The critical distinction between a craftsman and an expert is what happens after a sufficient level of expertise has been achieved. The expert will do everything she can to remain wedded to a single context, narrowing the scope of her learning, her practice, and her projects. The craftsman has the courage and himility to set aside her expertise and pick up an unfamiliar technology or learn a new domain."

Inline, Block, and Inline-Block Elements

March 09, 2013

This week I have been scrambling to play catch up with my apprenticeship since the week prior was dedicated to client work. I completed the box-object model project around the beginning of the week, and completed my most recent project on inline & block elements on early Friday.

Inline, block, and inline-block elements are not that difficult to understand, but pretty difficult to explain. I had a lot of fun exploring different color palettes this week, and discovering new ways to convey this sort of information to an audience. I can feel myself becoming more confident with my skills and being able to apply some things that I have been learning. Take a look at my project here: CSS: Inline, Block, and Inline-Block Elements.

Friday we spent hosting our first 8th Light University at the Tampa office. We had just been streaming Chicago's 8th Light University and inviting guests, but this will be so much more interactive and engaging with a live person talking and demonstrating. We kicked it off with Cory Foy's talk on Arduino programming. I'd never heard of this little kit before working here, so it was really neat to see how easy it can be to make your own robot that can do all kinds of incredible things. My coworker, Will, told me about someone who programmed the robot to open litter box doors when it sensed cats approaching, close the doors when it sensed cats leaving, and then start the fan blowing to dissipate the smell! Completely awesome. 10 out of 10, would buy.

This week I am going to try balancing client work and apprenticeship work so I don't fall so far behind on either. I should have a couple of book summaries up soon, and a project on CSS positioning.

Box-Object Model

March 06, 2013

Another project done, another several to go! :)

My objective for this project was to design a concise guide to the CSS Box-Object Model. I found it fun and kind of challenging. I think the thing that is the hardest is taking my newfound knowledge and implementation of semantic HTML and putting it to use instead of using the usual nondescript and number-laden names for things. Giving things more descriptive titles and utilizing new HTML5 tags is definitely something I am learning through doing, and making a habit.

Here is the completed project: The CSS Box-Object Model .

Balance

March 01, 2013

It has become increasingly hard trying to find a balance in my life between different projects and my personal life, though I realize it is something I must do. Learning discipline has been a priority for me in general, and now it's essential that I show I am capable of this balance.

Switching between client work and my apprenticeship projects is probably the hardest thing for me. It's great to be able to work on two drastically different things, but I find it hard to flip the switch in my brain between the two. This week I worked almost exclusively on client work, neglecting my apprenticeship projects. Next week I will probably work a lot on apprenticeship projects just to catch up.

That being said, I am having fun and learning a lot. Jekyll is a templating language for Clojure that I have been learning. Lots of brackets and parentheses. But I am finding that it comes easier with practice (and mistakes).

Skill Assesment (Finally!)

February 24, 2013

So, I originally had this project done on Friday, as was planned. I felt "eh" about it, and my mentor, Justin, looked at it and pointed out a bunch of things that he disliked. It was clear that I wasn't super passionate and excited about the project, so I took it home to rectify that.

I trimmed everything down quite a bit and focused on making things responsive. I muted the colors significantly so that my blog wasn't in danger of being an eyesore, even on different displays.

Anyway, the project is pretty self-explanitory. I was asked to asses my current skills and make the progress bars so that they could be edited to reflect how I've grown over the course of the apprenticeship. You can find the project here.

I used things I learned both through Handcrafted CSS and Craftsman Stephanie Briones' blog. I implemented figure and figcaption, both of which I'd never used before. Learning semantic tags in HTML5 is awesome and I know it makes my code so much cleaner. I am actually proud to show people what I've done now.

More CSS tweaks

February 19, 2013

Lots of tweaks still today. Lots of what I am doing with my self-evaluation is just making sure things flow well and the colors and fonts look good together. Right now, I am not going to worry about responsiveness because I am just starting to learn about it.

I am also going to be working on an actual client project which is very exciting, but becoming a top priority so I won't be able to do as many projects a week as I had planned.

I have really been getting into both lately, and am happy to be able to share the resources with the rest of the design team.

CSS Progress Bars

February 19, 2013

Today, for me, was all about CSS positioning and fun progress bars. I am currently working on a project where I evaluate my skillset coming into the apprenticeship. I wanted to show this through progress bars that had a little bit of drop shadow detail, a little bit of text, and some cool blurred images in the background. I wanted to mimic a really cool layout style that I've seen before, and that my co-apprentice Adam Kaplan executed for his positioning project.

I won't elaborate too much because I will have to complete this same project soon--but I had to use a bunch of new CSS that I'd never used before. It was fun to learn and looks great so far. My goal is to have it complete by Thursday or so. It would be great to be done Wednesday, but.. we'll see.

Semantic HTML Menu

February 14, 2013

My first non-blog-related project for my apprenticeship was to create a semantic HTML version of a restaurant menu. CSS could be used for simple styles and positioning, but no images could be used. I would use HTML elements to make the code simple, and easy to read and comprehend.

While this project seems simple, it took a lot more thought than I figured it would require.

Teaching myself HTML and CSS was a bit of a trainwreck composed of hacking bits of code together and having it work--but just barely. So I knew that learning to write everything myself from top to bottom would be a real challenge.

For this project, I read Expressive HTML by Billy Whited. I basically started by just writing up a simple HTML document, as I normally would. It was funny to go back and see how the way that I write my HTML mimics the way I would hack different pieces of code together to make sites---disjoined and very ungraceful. I quickly learned that I hardly had any deep understanding of the languages I thought I knew. With the help of my mentor, I was able to make my code more concise and flow a lot better. I feel like I have a more structured and thorough understanding.

You'll find my complete project here, and the original menu here. The Refinery is one of our favorite restaurants in Tampa and is well-known for changing their menu up weekly to reflect their fresh farmers' market finds.

I will end my post with a snippet from Billy's post that really summarized my experience:

Expressive html isn’t fundamentally different from “regular” html. It’s not an abstraction. It’s not a new tool. It doesn’t seek to alter the basic vocabulary of the web’s common language.

In fact, even if you aren’t familiar with the term “Expressive html,” I can guarantee you already know how to make use of it.

Rather, Expressive html is simply a different way of seeing, interpreting and authoring markup. It is:

A mindset.
An approach.
A departure.
A mantra.

Week Two

February 09, 2013

My second week totally flew by!

Most of it was spent getting my blog up and doing more reading. Like I mentioned before, I got the chance to begin work on a client project, which was a little intimidating but still very exciting.

A bunch of books came in the mail that were supposed to get here Monday or Tuesday, so I'll be doing that this weekend! So excited; I love designer books since they're usually short, have a ton of pictures, and are always so beautiful.

The Design of Everyday Things

February 08, 2013

Next on my reading list was The Design of Everyday Things, by Donald Norman. The book was actually first published in the year I was born, but the ideas and principles in the book remain relevant.

As we move through our world, we are met with thousands of choices--most, if not all of which we are unaware. In my morning routine alone, I am met with hundreds of decisions based on the appliances and hardware that I am using. Using a coffee machine, faucets, doors and windows..

Obviously, detailing all the points of this book would be laborious. Some of the points I found most interesting and helpful for our purposes were centered around making difficult things simple. In software design, we are tasked with putting hundreds of different functions into something that should look streamlined, friendly, while also being intuitive. We expect people to know or understand how to do certain things, where to look next, how to get back to what they were doing before.. there are so many things to take into consideration when designing things that can essentially become such a huge part of someone's everyday life.

A great example of this would be Apple products. Where having one button for every single function on an Apple device would become distracting, clunky, and cluttered, Apple utilizes intuitive gestures like flicking, pinching, spreading, and using multiple fingers for certain commands. It uses one of Don Norman's ideas--using both knowledge from the world and knowledge in the head.

I have argued that people learn better and feel more comfortable when the knowledge required for a task is available externally--either explicit in the world or readily derived through constraints. But knowledge in the world is useful only if there is a natural, easily interpreted relationship between that knowledge and the information it is intended to convey about possible actions and outcomes. - Donald Norman, The Design Of Everyday Things.

Apple's gestures perfectly illustrate this point. The gestures are natural to use because they mimic things we do outside of computing--say, flipping a page in a book or rotating a piece of paper on a flat surface. Gestures that we know well and have done before, sometimes without even realizing it, but things that just seem to make sense when applied in this way.

Thinking With Type

February 02, 2013

Typography holds a special place in my heart; its importance is undeniable, yet, it is often overlooked. Pinterest and Tumblr have popularized hand-lettering, helping people realize typography's role in computer- and print-based media.

Thinking With Type by Ellen Lupton has been on my Amazon wish list for a while, so I was excited to learn that it'd be the first item on my reading list for my apprenticeship at 8th Light. I actually finished the book before my first day.

This book is an excellent resource; akin to how we'd use a dictionary to refer to words just within our grasp, but the true meaning escapes us. Thinking With Type delves into the deeper elements of typography, even past the letters, down into the most minute details like serifs, bowls, ascender and descender. The way Ellen Lupton describes type in the most sensual ways is really what gets me.

"A well-designed comma carries the essence of the typeface down to its delicious details. Helvetica's comma is a chunky square mounted to a jaunty curve, while Bodoni's is a voluptuous, thin-stemmed orb." - Ellen Lupton, Thinking With Type

The book also covers numerous other type-related topics from kerning to utilizing the golden mean in creating a modular scale. Thinking With Type is an incredibly useful resource, and even has a website briefly covering all of the topics.

My First Week

February 01, 2013

It was really a stroke of luck for me to find out about this opportunity, and I'm so thankful I did. I can already safely say that I have never liked a job more, or worked with people who are so smart, who I can relate to as much as I am. People who I can talk to about anything I care about, and they just get it.

My first week here has just been getting handed books, given projects, and learning about the team and the way the company works. It's true--you do learn a lot, and quickly. This week, I used Github and got super frustrated. My first project was diving head-first into things I am not comfortable with in the least. By the end of the week, I was told I'd be working on client work. Yeah, fast. I love it!

My task for the next two weeks was to create a blog to post my book reviews and my projects for reference and for others to see. I am told this blog will morph and change much during my apprenticeship, so I am starting with something very basic--just a one-column design with some watercolor elements that I will vectorize in Illustrator to make them transparent .pngs. I wanted something to show off my style but something that I'd be able to evolve over time.

The next book on my reading list is The Design of Everyday Things by Donald Norman, so I will be posting a little entry about that soon.
